metadata.title: Sustainable synthesis and remarkable adsorption capacity of MOF/graphene oxide and MOF/CNT based hybrid nanocomposites for the removal of Bisphenol A from water

Sustainable synthesis and remarkable adsorption capacity of MOF/ graphene oxide and MOF/CNT based hybrid nanocomposites for the removal of Bisphenol A from water
MdAriful Ahsan a,g,⁎, Vahid Jabbari b, Md Tariqul Islam a, Reagan S. Turley a,g, Noemi Dominguez c, Hoejin Kim d, Edison Castro a, Jose Angel Hernandez-Viezcas a, Michael L. Curry e, Jorge Lopez f, Jorge L. Gardea-Torresdey a,g, Juan C. Noveron a,g,⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX 79968, United States b Department of Chemistry, Southern Methodist University, Dallas, TX 75205, United States c Department of Metallurgical, Materials and Biomedical Engineering, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX 79968, United States d Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX 79968, United States e Department of Chemistry, Tuskegee University, Tuskegee, AL 36088, United States f Department of Physics, University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX 79968, United States g Nanosystems Engineering Research Center for Nanotechnology-Enabled Water Treatment, The University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, United States
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Developing a green and facile solvothermal method to make MOFsbased hybrid nanocomposites • Crystalline and nano-sized Cu-BDC MOFs are decorated over GrO and CNT platforms. • The developed hybrid nanocomposites are used as adsorbent for water treatment. • Achieving a very high adsorption capacity of 182 mg/g toward BPA adsorption • The BPA adsorption can be explained by π–π interaction and H-bonding mechanism.
⁎ Corresponding authors at: Department of Chemistry, E-mail addresses: mahsan2@miners.utep.edu (M.A. Ah
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.03.219 0048-9697/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 16 January 2019 Received in revised form 14 March 2019 Accepted 14 March 2019 Available online 27 March 2019
Editor: Paola Verlicchi
A series of novel absorbents based on Cu-BDCMOFs decorated over graphene oxide (GrO) and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) hybrid nanocomposites, namely Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT, are synthesized via a facile and one-pot green solvothermal method for water remediation. The nanocomposites were characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS, Raman, FTIR, TGA, XPS, Zetasizer and ICP-OES instruments. XRD results confirmed the high crystalline structure of the synthesized hybrid nanocomposites. Morphological analysis by SEM and TEM verified the successful decoration of nano-sized Cu-BDC MOFs over GrO and CNT platforms; whereas, EDS and XPS analysis confirmed the presence of all components in the hybrid nanocomposites. Bisphenol A was used in this study as a model organic pollutant that is sometimes present in the industrial wastewater to test the adsorption capacity of the prepared hybrid nanomaterials toward their removal from water. The hybrid nanomaterials showed remarkable adsorption capacity of 182.2 and 164.1 mg/g toward the removal of BPA, which was several times higher than that of 60.2 mg/g for Cu-BDC MOF itself. The Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and D-R isotherm models were applied to analyze the experimental data and the results revealed that the Freundlich model describes the Keywords: Bisphenol A Cu-BDC MOF Carbon nanotubes Graphene oxide
University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX 79968, United States. san), jcnoveron@utep.edu (J.C. Noveron).
experimental data best. A kinetic study was carried out and it showed that the prepared nanomaterials could remove maximum amount of BPA from water in 30 min. The pseudo-first order, pseudo-second order and intraparticle diffusion models were applied to evaluate the kinetic data and the results suggested that the kinetics data could be well fitted to the pseudo-second order kinetic model. Additionally, the BAP adsorption process onto the hybrid nanocomposites was spontaneous and exothermic. The π-π interactions between the BPA and hybrid nanomaterials played a vital role during the BPA adsorption process. The higher adsorption capacity and water stability makes them a good candidate for water remediation applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to its low cost, ease of operation, and versatility, adsorption processes attracted the attention of many researchers and industries especially petrochemical and refining industries (Jabbari et al., 2016; Ahsan et al., 2018a; Jin et al., 2018). The main element of the adsorption process is solid porous medium (Huang et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2014). This media provides a high specific surface area or pore volume to absorb and remove the air and water contaminants (Peng et al., 2013; Shah et al., 2013). Although, a large variety of adsorbents capable of various pollutants adsorption have been reported, but traditional adsorbent materials have limitations in their application such as low adsorption capacity or difficulty being separated. Hence, there is an urgent need for an efficient and cost-effective adsorbent that presents large capacity, fast uptake rate and easy separation, at which porous materials can be suitable candidates.
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered as novel high potential crystalline adsorbents with highly porous structures, ample surface area and tunable surface chemistry (Jin et al., 2018; Li et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2015; Zhuang et al., 2012). MOFs are formed into ordered 3Dnetworks through self-assembly ofmetallic ions and organic ligands, which are mainly carboxylates and sulfonates. They have been widely used as an adsorbent for pollutant adsorption and water and air purification (Huang et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2014; Peng et al., 2013). Although, MOFs themselves demonstrate very promising physical and chemical properties for pollutant adsorption, their adsorbing capacity can be further improved by modifying their physicochemical properties and structures. To address this, graphene oxide (GrO) and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are themost appropriatematerials which can act as an excellent platform to growMOFs (Petit et al., 2011; Petit et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012; Petit and Bandosz, 2011; Petit and Bandosz, 2012). GrO and CNTs consist of graphene layers with various oxygen-containing functional groups (hydroxyl, carboxylic, epoxy, carbonyl) on the planes and edges of graphene layers (Hamadanian et al., 2013; Hamadanian et al., 2014; Hamadanian et al., 2017). Due to their numerous advantages such as low cost, non-toxicity, tunable surface chemistry and ease of functionalization with various materials, GrO and CNTs are considered promising precursors for composite making and numerous GrO and CNTs based composites have been reported (Hamadanian et al., 2013; Hamadanian et al., 2014; Hamadanian et al., 2017; Bai and Shen, 2012; Zhang et al., 2011). In fact, bare MOF's structure is full of void and free spaces due to weak dispersive forces, which is adverse for their applications such as retention of small molecules. However, the formation of MOFs in the presence of graphene layers of GrO and CNTs platforms leads to increases of dispersive forces and suppression of aggregation in MOFs (Petit et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012). Another advantage of GrO and CNTs platforms is controlling MOF's physicochemical properties, for example, morphology, structure and size during its formation (Petit and Bandosz, 2011; Petit and Bandosz, 2012).
Due to promising features of the hybrid nanocomposites of MOF with GrO and CNTs, these nanomaterials show promising capacity toward small molecules adsorption andwater and air purification. Jabbari et al., reported the synthesis of highly efficient adsorbents based on magnetic Cu3(BTC)2@GO and Cu3(BTC)2@CNT hybrid nanocomposites at which nano-sized MOFs are decorated over graphene functionalities
of GrO and CNTs. Due to synergistic effect, the hybrid materials showed significantly higher adsorption capacity toward organic pollutants compared to parent materials of Cu3(BTC)2, CNTs, and GrO (Jabbari et al., 2016). MOF-5/GrO hybrid composites were synthesized by Bandosz and his co-workers to increase dispersive forces in MOFs through the presence of graphene layers, which the findings showed promising physicochemical properties that were absent in the sole MOF (Petit and Bandosz, 2009). Recently, MOF-5/GrO and Cu-BTC/GrO composites were synthesized by Bandosz and Petit and similar porosity and crystalline structure of the compositeswere observed compared to that of parent MOFs (Bandosz and Petit, 2011). Petit et al. also reported synthesis of composites of MOFs and GrO (Petit et al., 2011; Petit et al., 2010; Petit and Bandosz, 2011; Petit and Bandosz, 2012). The prepared composite materials were applied for adsorption of toxic gases including H2S, NH3 andNO2. They havewitnessed 10% and 30% gas adsorption enhancement for NH3 andH2S, respectively and little improvement in NO2 adsorption over the composites compared to that of parentMOFs (Petit and Bandosz, 2012). Recently, successful synthesis and gas adsorption of Zn3(BTC)2 MOF and GrO-based hybrid composites was reported by Huang et al., (Huang et al., 2012). The findings illustrated that addition of optimal content of GrO during the MOF formation resulted in enhanced gas adsorption property of the MOF (Huang et al., 2012). Very recently, the successful synthesis of Cu3(BTC)2@CNT and MOF-5@CNT was reported (Xiang et al., 2011a; Yang et al., 2009). The prepared hybrid composites showed enhanced gas separation and selectivity over CO2/CH4 mixture and H2 uptake compared to the parent MOFs (Xiang et al., 2011a; Yang et al., 2009).
To best of our knowledge, there is no report on synthesis of Cu-BDC@ GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT as adsorbents for the removal of BPA from the water. BPA is considered one of the most important endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) that can affect the regular function of hormones causing numerous health effects in aquatic animals bydisrupting their reproductive systems (Ahsan et al., 2018b; Ahsan et al., 2018c; Ahsan et al., 2018d). Furthermore, it also affects the function of male reproduction adversely as well as disrupts the function of thyroid, related with hypertension, cardiovascular diseases andmetabolic syndromes. It has been used widely as a monomer for the production of epoxy resins, polycarbonates and many other plastics (Wang et al., 2019; Sobhanardakani and Zandipak, 2018). It has been detected in different concentrations in drinking water (0.317 μg/L), stream water (12 μg/L) and waste of landfill leachate (17.2 mg/L) (Javed et al., 2018). The concentrations at which the BPA can induce endocrine effects differ widely and the reported values are ranging from 1 to 1000 μg/L (U.S, 2010). Therefore, their removal from wastewater is significant to protect aquatic life and ensure human health. In fact, there are several principal factors whichmake this study important: (1) synthesis of nanocomposites based onMOFs, GrO, and CNTs is still a new idea, compared to their vast potential applications. Hence, there is a large area of investigation in bringing up new physical and chemical ways in fabrication and application of those hybrid nanocomposites; (2) in the previous studies MOFs are the dominant component in the composites, and since MOFs have been the main substrate in the previous studies, mixture composites rather than covalently bonded composites were synthesized. We are interested in having the GrO and CNTs substrates as main components to grow chemically-bonded nano-sized and well-dispersed
MOFs over the substrates; (3)moreover, there is no previous reports on the synthesis of Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT as adsorbents. Hence, the current study deals with synthesis and application of hybrid nanocomposites of Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT as adsorbents to remove BPA from the water. Successful synthesis and application of the developed hybrid nanocomposites are verified by XRD, SEM, TEM, EDS, XPS, IR, Raman spectroscopy, TGA, and UV–Vis measurements and the results are discussed and compared.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Terepthelic acid or benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (BDC), N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF), Cu(NO3)2. 2.5 H2O, Bisphenol A (N97%), H2SO4, HCl, HNO3, H2O2 and KMnO4 were obtained from SigmaAldrich, Fisher Scientific, Alfa Aesar and Acros companies and used as received. Graphite powder was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (5–15 μm in length and 20–40 nm in diameter) was obtained from cheap tube. Milli-Q® instrument (Millipore Corporation) was used to obtain deionized (DI) water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of graphene oxide (GrO)
sections.text: Graphite powder was used as the starting material to prepare GrO and a modified hammer's method was followed for the synthesis of GrO(Jabbari et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of functionalized carbon nanotubes (F-CNTs)
sections.text: F-CNTs were obtained by the acid treatment of pristine MWCNTs as reported elsewhere (Hamadanian et al., 2013; Hamadanian et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of Cu-BDC MOF
sections.text: To synthesize Cu-BDC MOFs, at first, 1440 mg of Cu(NO3)2. 2.5 H2O was dissolved in 20 mL DI water and was mixed with a solution of 264 mg BDC dissolved in 20 mL DMF. The resulting solution was stirred for 10 min and then placed into a glass reactor and sealed tightly. The glass reactor was then placed in an oven and heated to 373 K for 24 h. After 24 h, the reactor was cooled down till it reaches the room temperature. Then, the solution was centrifuged under vacuum to collect the blue solid of Cu-BDC MOFs and washed with DMF and DI water for three times. Finally, the resulting blue solid was placed in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 12 h and fine blue powder is obtained.

sections.heading: 2.5. Synthesis of Cu-BDC@GrO nanocomposites
sections.text:
To make GrO based Cu-BDC MOF hybrid nanocomposites, GrO was dispersed at first in a DMF-water mixture with a ratio of 1:1 (v:v) and sonicated vigorously in an ice bath for an hour. Then, the solutions of Cu(NO3)2. 2.5 H2O and BDC were made in 10 mL of water and DMF, respectively. Afterward, the copper salt solution was poured into the GrO suspension and sonicated vigorously for 10 min. The BDC solution was then poured into the above solution mixture and sonicated vigorously for another 15min. The resultingmixturewas placed into a glass reactor and sealed and the reactor was then put in an oven for 24 h at 373 K. Afterwards, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. Black solids of Cu-BDC@GrO nanocomposites were collected through vacuum filtration and washed with DMF and DI water for three times. Finally, the resulting black solid was dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 12 h and a fine black powder of Cu-BDC@GrO was obtained. Three different types of Cu-BDC@GrO hybrid nanocomposites were prepared depending on Cu-BDC MOFs and GrO ratio: 1:1 (labeled as Cu1GrO1), 3:1
(labeled as Cu3GrO1) and 1:3 (labeled as Cu1GrO3). The schematic view of the formation of Cu-BDC@GrO nanocomposite is shown in Fig. S1.

sections.heading: 2.6. Synthesis of Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites
sections.text: The samemethodwas used for the synthesis of Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites. Here, functionalized CNTs were used instead of GrO to make the composites. Three different types of Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites were prepared depending on Cu-BDC MOFs and CNTs ratio: 1:1 (labeled as Cu1CNT1), 3:1 (labeled as Cu3CNT1) and 1:3 (labeled as Cu1CNT3).

sections.heading: 2.7. Characterization techniques of the prepared materials
sections.text: X-ray powder diffractometer was used to study the crystalline phases of newly synthesized hybrid nanocomposites along with their parent materials (Model: Bruker D8 Discover X-ray Diffractometer). The morphologies of the prepared nanocomposites were studied by using scanning electronmicroscopy (Model: Hitachi S-4800) and transmission electron microscopy (Model: Hitachi H-7650). An energy dispersive X-ray detector equipped with SEM was used to study the elemental composition of the prepared nanocomposites. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopymeasurements were performed to study the functional groups of the hybrid nanocomposites (Model: Thermo Scientific™ Nicolet iS5 FTIR Spectrometer). Thermogravimetric analysis was performed to study the thermal stability of the hybrid nanocomposites (Mettler Toledo thermogravimetric instrument). Xray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to study the binding energies (Model: PHI 5600 spectrometer). A DXR Smart Raman equipped with 532 nm laser was used to collect the Raman spectrum of the nanocomposites. A UV–Vis spectrophotometer was used to analyze the BPA solutions before and after adsorption on the nanocomposites (Model: Agilent Cary 50 Conc). The zeta potentialwasmeasured using aMalvern Instruments Zetasizer ZS-90 with a MPT-2 Titrator. Leaching test was conducted using an inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) manufactured by Perkin Elmer model Optima 4300DV.

sections.heading: 2.8. Batch adsorption studies
sections.text:
At first, 200 ppm of BPA stock solutionwas prepared in 2%methanol and then the desired concentration of BPA solution was made by diluting the stock solution for the adsorption study. For the batch adsorption studies, 10 mg of the nanocomposites were dispersed in 20 mL of 50–200 ppm BPA solution, whereas, 20 mg of nanocomposites and 40 mL of 20 ppm BPA solution were used for the time dependent study. For the pH study, 10 mg of adsorbent and 20 mL of 50 ppm BPA solution were used. The batch adsorption studies were performed at pH 4. The solution mixtures were bath sonicated for 30 min and then placed in a magnetic stirrer for 24 h with constant stirring. Afterward, 1 mL of solution from each sample was filtered through a 0.45 μm syringe filter (PETE) and analyzed by a UV–vis spectroscopy to calculate the adsorption capacity of the prepared hybrid nanomaterials. The adsorption capacity (mg/g) of the nanomaterials was calculated using the following equation (Jabbari et al., 2016; Ahsan et al., 2018a).
Qe ¼ C0−Ceð Þ V
m ð1Þ
where Ce is the equilibrium concentration of the BPA solution, Co is the initial concentration of the BPA solution, m is the weight of the nanomaterials (mg), V is the volume of the BPA solution (mL), and Qe is the adsorption capacity of the nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3.1. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD)
sections.text: Crystalline patterns were collected through XRD analysis to identify the crystalline structure of the prepared hybrid nanomaterials along with their parent materials and shown in Fig. 1. According to the XRD results, highly crystalline Cu-BDC MOFs are successfully formed over GrO and CNT platforms at which all the characteristic peaks of the MOFs appear in the pattern (Shete et al., 2018; Yim and Jeon, 2015; Liu et al., 2012). These results are in well agreement with previous reports, suggesting successful decoration of MOFs over these platforms (Jabbari et al., 2016; Bandosz and Petit, 2011; Xiang et al., 2011b; Zhu and Xu, 2014). In the case of Cu-BDC@GrO hybrid nanocomposites (Fig. 1a), at lowCu-BDCMOFs dosage, veryweak signal of GrO at around 2θ = 12 is detectable, but at high dosage of the MOFs, there are no evident peaks representing GrO, which the reason can be due to high surface coverage of the GrO substrate by the MOFs and significant exfoliation of the graphene layers (Jabbari et al., 2016; Petit et al., 2011; Petit et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012). Regarding the Cu-BDC@ CNT hybrid nanocomposites (Fig. 1b), a sharp signal at 2θ~25 relate to CNT substrate present in all the prepared samples, however, in a higher content of theMOFs, the signals related to the Cu-BDCMOFs rise drastically (Jabbari et al., 2016). No peak corresponding to impurities is detected, which shows successful synthesis and compositing of the CuBDCMOF, GrO, and CNT parent materials. It is also evident that the prepared composites are binary hybrid nanocomposites rather than a physicalmixture of theMOFswith GrO and CNT (Petit et al., 2011; Petit et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012; Xiang et al., 2011a; Yang et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphological characteristic
sections.text:
Morphological studies of the developed Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@ CNT hybrid nanocomposites and their parent components are carried out through SEM (Fig. S2) and TEM (Fig. 2) microscopes. SEM and TEM micrographs of GrO (Fig. 3a and Fig. 4a) show exfoliated layers of graphite oxide which are stacked together (Jabbari et al., 2016; Hamadanian et al., 2017; Petit and Bandosz, 2009; Bandosz and Petit, 2011). Successful acid-treatment and functionalized of pristine CNTs without considerable decomposition and deformation of the nanotubes are also shown in Fig. S2b and Fig. 2b (Hamadanian et al., 2013; Hamadanian et al., 2014). SEM images (Fig. S2c) also show aggregated cubic particles of the Cu-BDC MOFs which is confirmed using TEM image of Fig. 2c. SEM and TEM images of Cu1GrO1 (Fig. S2d and Fig. 2d) and Cu1GrO3 (Fig. S2e and Fig. 2e), show successful decoration of nano-sized Cu-BDCMOFs over graphene layers of GrO (Jabbari et al., 2016; Huang et al., 2012; Hamadanian et al., 2017; Petit and Bandosz, 2009; Bandosz and Petit, 2011). In case of CNT-based hybrid nanomaterials of Cu1CNT3 (Fig. S2f and Fig. 2f), similar findings for
Fig. 1. XRD analysis of (a) Cu-BDC@GrO and (
GrO-based hybrid nanocomposites successful loading of Cu-BDC MOFs over CNT surface is observed (Bandosz and Petit, 2011; Xiang et al., 2011a). Overall, the morphological findings show that Cu-BDC MOFs are successfully decorated over GrO and CNT surfaces. Furthermore, it was found that compared to bare Cu-BDC MOFs, which are in several microns, the presence of graphene layers in GrO and CNT platforms results in well-dispersed and nano-sized Cu-BDCMOFs, resulting inMOFs with higher surface area as well as formation of numerous pores between theMOFs and the substrates, which are favorable for the adsorption of small molecules like organic pollutants (Jabbari et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 3.3. Elemental study by EDS and XPS
sections.text:
To analyze the elemental structure of the synthesized Cu-BDC MOFs and it's hybrid nanocomposites, EDS analysis was carried out and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. S3. According to the findings, the presence of the elements of Cu, C, and O in all samples verify successful synthesis of the hybrid nanocomposites.
To further verify successful synthesis of the hybrid nanocomposites, XPS test was conducted. As shown in Fig. 3, C, O and Cu are present in the prepared Cu-BDC@GrO hybrid nanocomposite. The characteristic signals of C1s and O1s related to GrO and BDC ligand appear at 287 eV and 534 eV, respectively (Jabbari et al., 2016; Elder et al., 2017). Cu 2p1/2 and Cu2p3/2 deriving from the coppermetal segment of thehybrid nanocomposite show signals at around 955 eV and 934 eV, respectively, and the findings are in good agreement with the previous reports (Jabbari et al., 2016; Xiang et al., 2011a).

sections.heading: 3.4. Chemical properties: FTIR and Raman studies
sections.text:
The chemical structure of the prepared Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@ CNT hybrid nanocomposites and their parent components was investigated by FTIR spectroscopy and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. S4. The prepared Cu-BDC MOF shows signals at 2980 cm−1 for C\\H stretching of the aromatic rings, 2890 cm−1 for symmetric CH in –CH2–, 2950 cm−1 for asymmetric CH in –CH2–, 3392 cm−1 for–OH or O\\H deriving from absorbed or coordinated water molecules, 1590 and 1640 cm−1 for asymmetric vibrations in –CO2–, 1730 cm−1 for C_O stretching, 1370 and 1455 cm−1 related to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of the carboxylate groups that are present in the BDC linker, and 1110 cm−1 corresponding to C–O–Cu vibration in the Cu-BDC MOF (Shete et al., 2018; Yim and Jeon, 2015; Liu et al., 2012; Elder et al., 2017). Regarding Cu-BDC@GrO hybrid nanocomposites, the characteristic signals related to the parent materials appear in the FTIR spectra which verify successful hybridization of the parentmaterials (Jabbari et al., 2016; Petit et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012; Bandosz and Petit, 2011). Additionally, there is a change in intensities of the signals at 1455/1376 cm−1 and 1570/1628 cm−1 in the hybrid nanocomposites which can correspond to variation in the environment of the
b) Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites.
BDC's carboxylate ligands, or in other words, interactions between BDC ligands of the MOF and functional groups of GrO (Huang et al., 2012; Bandosz and Petit, 2011). Furthermore, the presence of higherMOF content in the hybrid nanomaterials results in higher intensities of the MOFs signals, which is deriving from higher MOFs loading (Jabbari et al., 2016; Petit et al., 2010).
Fig. S5 shows the Raman spectra of the as-synthesized Cu1CNT3 hybrid nanocomposite and F-CNT. The Raman spectra of the F-CNT sample shows two peaks at around 450 and 790 cm−1 for D andG bands, respectively. The D-band is attributed to j-point phonons of the A1g symmetry, whereas the G band can be ascribed to the E2g phonon of the sp2 carbon atoms, (Kumar et al., 2013; Seo et al., 2009; Kudin et al., 2008). In another word, the D-band is a usual sign of the presence of defects in graphitic structure and the G-band is a feature of graphitic layers corresponding to tangential vibration of the carbon atoms. According to Fig. S5, spectra of the Cu1CNT3 hybrid nanocomposite preserves main characteristic peaks of the parent materials, denoting that the chemical structure of the parent materials remains intact upon making the composition.

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
TGA analysis corresponding to thermogram curves of Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites along with the MOF are shown in Fig. 4. The spectra of Cu-BDC MOFs show signals related to mass loses at around 110 °C as a result of dehydration and 320 °C deriving from degradation of the coordinated hydroxyl groups and moisture,
decomposition of excessive water, at which more decomposition of the MOFs occurs at around 410 °C (Shete et al., 2018; Yim and Jeon, 2015; Liu et al., 2012; Elder et al., 2017). Our findings show that the hybrid nanocomposites of Cu-BDC@GrO show very similar pattern to their parent materials (Jabbari et al., 2016; Petit et al., 2010; Bandosz and Petit, 2011). It is also observed that at higherMOF content in the nanocomposites, the curve is very similar to the parent of MOFs and vice versa. Also, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites show relatively higher thermal stability in comparison to the parent materials that is likely due to a chemical bonding between the MOFs and the substrates.

sections.heading: 3.6. BPA adsorption study
sections.text:
To investigate one of the potential applications of these prepared hybrid nanomaterials, they were utilized as effective adsorbents for BPA removal in water as one of the organic pollutants (Zhang et al., 2019). The adsorption performance of the Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites alongwith their parentmaterials are summarized in Table 1. It is clear that the newly formed CuMOF-based hybrid nanocomposites have shown a significant improvement in the adsorption capacity for the removal of BPA, compared to the parent materials. The higher adsorption capacity of the newly prepared hybrid nanomaterials is attributed to the synergetic effects of the parent materials that are present in the composite materials. It was found that functionalized graphene layer benefits MOF formation by suppression of aggregation, increasing dispersive forces, different morphology and size, less inter-
MOFs voids, and formation of new small pores, while preserving the MOF formation and growth. This phenomenon ultimately results in a good dispersion of MOF structures and subsequently activate the synergistic effect of the parent materials which exist in the hybrid nanocomposites. Moreover, it aids in preventing the distortions and buckling/ bundling of the GrO and CNTs, which helps to sustain the morphology and size of the synthesized hybrid nanocomposites. Additionally, new pores could be formed at the interface of Cu-BDC MOF/GrO and CuBDC MOF/CNT due to the chemical binding of the Cu-BDC MOF to the graphene layers in CNTs andGrO,which is favorable for small molecules like BPA adsorption. Furthermore, the adsorption capacity of the hybrid nanomaterials is comparable with many other adsorbents that are previously reported as shown in Table 1. From the table, it is clear that the
Fig. 4. TGA analysis of Cu-BDC MOFs, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanoc
adsorption capacity of the Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites are several times higher than the activated carbons, carbon nanotubes and different types of carbonaceous materials (Nakanishi et al., 2002; Asada et al., 2004; Kuo, 2009). Therefore, due to the outstanding features deriving from the synergetic effects as well as the high adsorption capacity, we think that these newly synthesized hybrid nanomaterials can be potentially utilized for wastewater treatment technologies.

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorbent dosage study
sections.text:
The effect of different adsorbent doses on the BPA adsorption by CuBDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites are
omposites of Cu1GrO1, Cu3GrO1, Cu1GrO3, Cu1CNT1, Cu3CNT1 and Cu1CNT3.
given in Fig. S6·In this regard, 20mL of 100 ppmBPA solution was used with different adsorbent dose, viz. 5, 10, 15 and 20mg. From thefigure it is clear that the adsorption capacity of the preparedmaterials increased with the increasing adsorbent dose as the contact surface of the adsorbents increased. Once the dose amount is increased, it enhances the number of available active sites for the BPA adsorption, therefore making the penetration easier for BPA to the adsorption sites.

sections.heading: 3.8. Initial concentration dependent and isotherm study
sections.text:
The adsorption isothermmodels can tell how the adsorbed BPAmolecules distribute between the liquid and solid phases when the equilibrium of the adsorption process is reached. The isotherm study was carried out by using different BPA solutions viz. 50, 100, 150 and 200 ppm. The initial concentration dependent study is given in Fig. S7. From the figure, it is apparent that the adsorption capacity of the adsorbents increases initially and then after a certain point it does not increase anymore. This is due to the presence of available active sites of the adsorbents to interact with the BPA molecule and when it gets saturated, then it does not adsorb more. Four different isotherm models such as Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin Radushkevich (DR) were used in this study to analyze the experimental data of the BPA adsorption process (Zandipak et al., 2019; Sobhanardakani and Zandipak, 2017; Zandipak and Sobhanardakani, 2018; Ahsan et al., 2018e; Fasfous et al., 2010; Islam et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2004). The isotherm equations are expressed by the following equations.
Langmuir isotherm model : Ce Qe ¼ 1 QmaxKL þ Ce Qmax
ð2Þ
Freundlich isotherm model : ln Qeð Þ ¼ ln K Fð Þ þ 1 n ln Ceð Þ ð3Þ
Temkin isotherm model : Qe ¼ BlnaT þ BlnCe ð4Þ
Where;B ¼ RT bT
ð5Þ
D−R isotherm model : lnQe ¼ lnQm−βε2 ð6Þ
Where; ε ¼ RTln 1þ 1=Ceð Þ ð7Þ
where Qe and Qmax are the adsorption capacity and maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g), Ce is the concentration at equilibrium (mg/L), KL is the Langmuir constant (L/mg), 1/n is the intensity of the sorption process, KF is the Freundlichmodel constant, R is the universal gas constant, T is the temperature (K), B and bT is the Temkin constant, β is the activity coefficient and ε is the Polanyi potential. The isotherm fitting results are shown in Fig. 5 and the calculated relevant parameters are given in Table 2.
It is clear that the Freundlich isotherm model fits the experimental data best as compared to the Langmuir, Temkin and D-R isotherm models due to the fact that it has higher determination coefficient (R2) values for all the adsorbents toward the removal of BPA as shown in Table 2. Therefore, it is suggested that the BPA adsorption is multilayered type on the heterogeneous surface of the adsorbents. The results further revealed that the physical interactions might play a vital role during the biosorption process. The heterogeneity factor, 1/n represents the bond distribution and the value of 1/n usually lies between 0 and 1. Furthermore, the smaller 1/n value is, the more favorable sorption process will be (Ahsan et al., 2018e; Fasfous et al., 2010; Islam et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2004). The 1/n values are ranging from 0.36 to 0.69 for the BPA adsorption process by the Cu-BDC MOF and their hybrid nanocomposites, which favors the sorption process of BPA.

sections.heading: 3.9. Kinetic study
sections.text:
The sorption time is a key factor in the adsorption study and their effect on the BPA adsorption by the Cu-BDC MOF, MOF@GrO and MOF@ CNT hybrid nanocomposites is shown in Fig. 6a. The time dependent study of the BPA adsorption clearly demonstrates that the adsorption performance of the GrO and CNT based nanocomposites are much better than the MOF itself. This is due to the fact that the incorporation of GrO and CNT into the MOFmaking the nanocomposites well dispersed, which could create more active sites that can interact with the MB and increase the sorption capacity of the Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanomaterials. Furthermore, the hybrid nanocomposites adsorb themaximumamount of BPA from solution,whereas the soleMOF itself only adsorbs about 20%. That means the incorporation of GrO and CNT into the MOF structure not only increases the adsorption capacity but also makes the sorption process much faster as compared to the MOF.
Kinetic studies of any adsorption process are critical to identify the rate of the process as well as offer some valuable information for adsorption mechanism analysis. Adsorption kinetics of the Cu-BDC MOF and their nanocomposites for the BPA adsorption are presented Fig. 6 (b–c). Pseudo-first order and pseudo-second order kinetic models were used in this study to fit the adsorption data, and they are expressed by the following Eqs. (8) and (9), respectively (Ahsan et al., 2018b; Ahsan et al., 2018c; Ahsan et al., 2018d).
log Qe−Qtð Þ ¼ log Qeð Þ− k1
2:303 t ð8Þ
t Qt ¼ 1 k2Qe 2 þ t Qe
ð9Þ
Where Qt and Qe (mg/g) denote the adsorption capacities of the adsorbents at time, t and at equilibrium, respectively; K1 is the pseudofirst order rate constant (min−1) and K2 is the pseudo-second-order rate constant (g mg−1 min−1).
The kinetic parameters of BPA adsorption onto the hybrid nanocomposites are summarized in Table 3. According to our findings, it could be concluded that the experimental data of BPA adsorption fitted to the pseudo-second order kinetic model as well as compared to the pseudo-first order model due to the higher R2 values. Furthermore, the calculated values of adsorption capacity are very close to the experimental values for the pseudo-second order model as compared to the pseudo-first kinetic order model.
Further, the intra-particle diffusion kinetic model was used in this study to evaluate the kinetic data of the BPA adsorption onto Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites and the results are given in Fig. S8. This model is usually applied to find the diffusion mechanism of the sorption process. The intra-particle diffusion
model is expressed by the following equation (Ahsan et al., 2018b; Ahsan et al., 2018c; Ahsan et al., 2018d).
Qt ¼ kit0:5 þ C ð10Þ
where Qt is the adsorption capacity of the Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites for BPA adsorption at time t, ki is the intra-particle rate constant and C is a constant that is related to boundary layer thickness. If the plot of Qt vs t1/2 provides a linear line with intercept C and slope kid, then the sorption follows this diffusion model (Ahsan et al., 2018b). Furthermore, when this plot for any sorption process passes through the origin that means this diffusion will be the only rate limiting process. On the other hand, if the data points give multi-linear plots, then two or more steps influence the sorption process. As seen from the figure, the kinetic data points are attached by two straight lines. The first line describes the mesopore and macropore type diffusion, whereas, the second one represents the micropore type diffusion (Ahsan et al., 2018b). It is clear from the figure that the straight lines obtained from the kinetic data of BPA adsorption are strayed from the origin and this is might be due to the difference in rate of mass transfer for the initial and final steps of sorption process. In addition, such kind of deviations demonstrate that the pore type diffusion is not only the rate controlling step. It can be concluded that the BPA adsorption process onto Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and CuBDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites does not follow the intra-particle diffusion kinetic model as the straight lines are deviated from the origin.

sections.heading: 3.10. Thermodynamics studies
sections.text:
Thermodynamic studies are very important for any adsorption process that can provide in-depth info about the inherent energy change and most importantly, this information helps to understand the
temperature effect on the adsorption process. In this regard, the BPA adsorption process onto the MOF@GrO and MOF@CNT hybrid nanocomposites was carried out at different temperatures viz. 298 K, 318 K and 338 K to investigate the impact of temperature on the BPA adsorption onto the nanocomposites and the results are shown in Fig. S9. It is evident and clear from the figure that the adsorption capacity of the hybrid nanocomposites decreases with the increasing temperature revealing that the adsorption process is favorable at low temperature (Ahsan et al., 2018b; Ahsan et al., 2018c; Ahsan et al., 2018d).
To calculate the thermodynamic parameters such as standard enthalpy change (ΔH°), standard Gibbs free energy (ΔG°), and standard entropy change (ΔS°), the following equations are generally used (Ahsan et al., 2018b; Ahsan et al., 2018c; Ahsan et al., 2018d).
lnKc ¼ −ΔH o RT þ ΔS o R ð11Þ
Kc ¼ QeCe ð12Þ
ΔGo ¼ −RTlnKc ð13Þ
where T is the absolute temperature, R is the universal gas constant and Kc is the unit less thermodynamic equilibrium constant. ΔS° and ΔH° values are calculated from the intercept and slope of the lnKc vs 1/T plot, respectively and the plot is shown in Fig. S10.
The obtained results from the thermodynamic studies are presented in Table 4. TheΔG° values are negative at all temperatures, demonstrating that the BPA adsorption occurs onto GrO and CNT based hybrid nanocomposites spontaneously in all cases, as well as the adsorption processes is thermodynamically favorable (Yu et al., 2004). Moreover, it can be seen from the table that the value ofΔG° increases with the increasing temperature form 298 K to 338 K, revealed that the lower temperature favors the adsorption process (Fasfous et al., 2010). The obtained values of ΔH° are negative for the BPA adsorption by the hybrid nanocomposites. The negative ΔH° values indicated the nature of
the adsorption reaction as exothermic. Besides, the decrease in capacity of the hybrid nanocomposites for BPA removal with increasing temperature supported this phenomenon. The physical and chemical adsorption processes can be defined based on the range of ΔH° values, for instance, ΔH° value of 2.1–20.9 kJ/mol is for physical adsorption and 80–200 kJ/mol for chemical adsorption (Liu, 2009). In this research, the obtained ΔH° values are −5.98 kJ/mol and − 2.74 kJ/mol for the BPA adsorption onto the Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites, respectively, demonstrating the BPA adsorption process is physical in both cases. Furthermore, the calculated ΔS° values are −17.46 Jmol−1 K−1 and− 7.99 Jmol−1 K−1, and the negativeΔS° values manifested decreased randomness at the sorbent-sorbate interface during the sorption of BPA onto the sorbent materials (Kuo, 2009; Fasfous et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 3.11. pH study and possible adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
The zeta potential or the surface charge of the adsorbent material depends on the solution pH. At a pH value represented as pHPZC or pH of the point of zero charge, the surface of the adsorbent has zero net charge, whereas, at a pH value higher than pHPZC, the surface of the adsorbent is negatively charged offering affinity for the electrostatic interactions with cationic pollutants (Sobhanardakani and Zandipak, 2018). But when the pH value is less than pHPZC, then the surface of the adsorbent is positively charged favoring the electrostatic interactions with anionic pollutants (Sobhanardakani and Zandipak, 2018). Therefore, the zeta potentials of Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites as a function of solution pH were investigated by varying the solution pH from 2 to 9.5 and the results are presented in Fig. 7a. The obtained pHPZC values were 2.82, 3.08 and 3.19 for Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites, respectively.
Solution pH plays a vital role in determining the underlying adsorption mechanism of an adsorption process. The pH can also influence the surface charging of adsorbent material as well as the dissociation state of the pollutant or adsorbate based on their dissociation constants (pKa). In this regard, the effect of pH on the adsorption of BPA by the MOF and their hybrid nanocomposites was studied at the range of 2 to 9 as shown in Fig. 7b. From thefigure, itwas observed that the adsorption capacity of the Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites increased slightly from pH 2 to 4 and then decreased significantly upon increasing pH to 9. This is because of the anionic structure of BPA and the pHpzc values of Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites. BPAhas a pKa value of 10.6. At pHb 10.6, BPAexists as its molecular form in the aqueous medium, whereas, at pH N 10.6, it exists as HBPA− or BPA2− (Sobhanardakani and Zandipak, 2018). From the pH of the point zero charge analysis, it can be concluded that the surface of the Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites will be positively charge when the pH is b2.82, 3.08 and
3.19, respectively and their surface will be negatively charged when the pH is N2.82, 3.08 and 3.19, respectively. Therefore, the surface of the adsorbents is getting negatively chargedwith increasing pH and as a result, electrostatic repulsion is occurred between the negatively charged BPA and adsorbents and therefore, lowers the adsorption capacity with increasing pH 4 to 9. Furthermore, the π–π interaction and H-bonding mechanismplay amajor role in that case for the BPA adsorption. The benzene rings of BPA molecule could interact with the aromatic structure of the Cu-BDC MOF, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites through π-π interactions as shown in Fig. 8 (Kim et al., 2013). In addition, H-bonding may happen between the O-containing groups such as OH, COOH of the nanocomposites and the functional groups in BAP including OH as H-receptors (He et al., 2016).
We also performed a pH dependent leaching test of the prepared CuBDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT nanocomposites after BPA adsorption and the results are presented in Fig. S11(a-b). The leaching concentration of Cu(II) from the Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@GrO samples were found to 56.64 and 96.11 ppm at very low pH of 2.83 and 2.68, respectively. But in both cases, the leaching concentration of Cu(II) was decreased drastically with the increasing pH. The leaching concentrations were found o.11 and 0.18 ppm at a pH of 9.33 and 9.01, respectively. We also observed very low levels of the metal from our samples at normal pH near 7 as most of the wastewater treatment is carried out at neutral pH.

sections.heading: 3.12. Reusability study
sections.text: A reusability study is very important in developing and designing an economical adsorbent material for utilizing in practical applications. In this regard, we did the reusability test of the developed Cu-BDC@GrO hybrid nanocomposites for BPA adsorption and the corresponding results are given in Fig. S12. For this test, 20 mL of 100 ppm BPA solution and 10mg of the adsorbent were used. The adsorbent waswashedwith ethanol and dried in a vacuum oven after each cycle to use for the next cycle. As seen in the figure, the adsorbent could use up to five cycles withminimal loss in adsorption capacity. This results indicate the highly stable nature of the newly prepared Cu-BDC@GrO adsorbents.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites-based adsorbents are synthesized and their adsorption capacity toward BPA as a model organic pollutant is studied. SEM and TEMmorphological analyses showed successful formation and bonding of Cu-BDC MOFs over GrO and CNT substrates, and IR and TGA measurements confirmed hybrid nature of the developed Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites atwhich own crystalline nature as shown byXRD analysis. Elemental analysis carried out on EDS and XPS showed presence of carbon, oxygen, and copper elements in the synthesized Cu-BDC@GrO
, Cu-BDC@GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites.
and Cu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites. Adsorption capacity of the developed nanocomposites were tested over BPA at which Cu-BDC@ GrO and Cu-BDC@CNT adsorbents showed superior performance compared to the parent materials and many reported MOFs- and carbon nanostructured-based adsorbents. The enhanced performance is attributed to compositing suitable materials and the synergistic effect and having many of desired characteristic of each component in the nanocomposites. Isotherm and kinetic studies were best fitted by Freundlich and pseudo-secondmodel, and the adsorption processes were exothermic and spontaneous at which the adsorption capacity decreased with raising temperature. Overall, these findings show that the developed Cu-BDC@GrO andCu-BDC@CNT hybrid nanocomposites own promising features and can be considered as good candidates for water remediation.
